sp.l: Welcome, my lord. What, will our mother come?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: On what occasion God He knows, not I,
The Queen your mother and your brother York
Have taken sanctuary. The tender prince
Would fain have come with me to meet your Grace,
But by his mother was perforce withheld.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course
Is this of hers!— Lord Cardinal, will your Grace
Persuade the Queen to send the Duke of York
Unto his princely brother presently?—
If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him,
And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.

sp.speaker: CARDINAL
sp.l: My lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory
Can from his mother win the Duke of York,
Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurate
To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid
We should infringe the holy privilege
Of blessèd sanctuary! Not for all this land
Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: You are too senseless obstinate, my lord,
Too ceremonious and traditional.
Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,
You break not sanctuary in seizing him.
The benefit thereof is always granted
To those whose dealings have deserved the place
And those who have the wit to claim the place.
This prince hath neither claimed it nor deserved it
And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it.
Then taking him from thence that is not there,
You break no privilege nor charter there.
Oft have I heard of sanctuary men,
But sanctuary children, never till now.

sp.speaker: CARDINAL
sp.l: My lord, you shall o’errule my mind for once.—
Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: I go, my lord.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.
Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,
Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Where it seems best unto your royal self.
If I may counsel you, some day or two
Your Highness shall repose you at the Tower;
Then where you please and shall be thought most fit
For your best health and recreation.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: I do not like the Tower, of any place.—
Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place,
Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Is it upon record, or else reported
Successively from age to age, he built it?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Upon record, my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: But say, my lord, it were not registered,
Methinks the truth should live from age to age,
As ’twere retailed to all posterity,
Even to the general all-ending day.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: So wise so young, they say, do never live long.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: What say you, uncle?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I say, without characters fame lives long.
Aside. Thus, like the formal Vice, Iniquity,
I moralize two meanings in one word.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: That Julius Caesar was a famous man.
With what his valor did enrich his wit,
His wit set down to make his valor live.
Death makes no conquest of this conqueror,
For now he lives in fame, though not in life.
I’ll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham—

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: What, my gracious lord?

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: An if I live until I be a man,
I’ll win our ancient right in France again
Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Short summers lightly have a forward spring.

div.stage: Enter young Duke of York, Hastings, and the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Now in good time here comes the Duke of York.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Richard of York, how fares our loving brother?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Well, my dread lord— so must I call you now.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours.
Too late he died that might have kept that title,
Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: How fares our cousin, noble lord of York?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: I thank you, gentle uncle. O my lord,
You said that idle weeds are fast in growth.
The Prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: He hath, my lord.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: And therefore is he idle?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: O my fair cousin, I must not say so.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Then he is more beholding to you than I.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: He may command me as my sovereign,
But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: My dagger, little cousin? With all my heart.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: A beggar, brother?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give,
And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: A greater gift than that I’ll give my cousin.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: A greater gift? O, that’s the sword to it.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ay, gentle cousin, were it light enough.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: O, then I see you will part but with light gifts.
In weightier things you’ll say a beggar nay.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: It is too heavy for your Grace to wear.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Little.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: My lord of York will still be cross in talk.
Uncle, your Grace knows how to bear with him.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me.—
Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me.
Because that I am little, like an ape,
He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!
To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,
He prettily and aptly taunts himself.
So cunning and so young is wonderful.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: My lord, will ’t please you pass along?
Myself and my good cousin Buckingham
Will to your mother, to entreat of her
To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: My Lord Protector needs will have it so.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Why, what should you fear?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Marry, my uncle Clarence’ angry ghost.
My grandam told me he was murdered there.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: I fear no uncles dead.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Nor none that live, I hope.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.
To York. But come, my lord. With a heavy heart,
Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.

div.stage: A sennet. Prince Edward, the Duke of York, and Hastings exit. Richard, Buckingham, and Catesby remain.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Think you, my lord, this little prating York
Was not incensèd by his subtle mother
To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: No doubt, no doubt. O, ’tis a parlous boy,
Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable.
He is all the mother’s, from the top to toe.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Well, let them rest.— Come hither, Catesby.
Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend
As closely to conceal what we impart.
Thou knowest our reasons, urged upon the way.
What thinkest thou? Is it not an easy matter
To make William Lord Hastings of our mind
For the installment of this noble duke
In the seat royal of this famous isle?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: He, for his father’s sake, so loves the Prince
That he will not be won to aught against him.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: What think’st thou then of Stanley? Will not he?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Well then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby,
And, as it were far off, sound thou Lord Hastings
How he doth stand affected to our purpose
And summon him tomorrow to the Tower
To sit about the coronation.
If thou dost find him tractable to us,
Encourage him and tell him all our reasons.
If he be leaden, icy, cold, unwilling,
Be thou so too, and so break off the talk,
And give us notice of his inclination;
For we tomorrow hold divided councils,
Wherein thyself shalt highly be employed.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Commend me to Lord William. Tell him, Catesby,
His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries
Tomorrow are let blood at Pomfret Castle,
And bid my lord, for joy of this good news,
Give Mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Good Catesby, go effect this business soundly.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: My good lords both, with all the heed I can.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: You shall, my lord.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: At Crosby House, there shall you find us both.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Now, my lord, what shall we do if we perceive
Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Chop off his head. Something we will determine.
And look when I am king, claim thou of me
The earldom of Hereford, and all the movables
Whereof the King my brother was possessed.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: I’ll claim that promise at your Grace’s hand.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: And look to have it yielded with all kindness.
Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards
We may digest our complots in some form.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter a Messenger to the door of Hastings.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: My lord, my lord.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Who knocks?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: One from the Lord Stanley.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: What is ’t o’clock?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Upon the stroke of four.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Cannot my Lord Stanley sleep these tedious nights?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: So it appears by that I have to say.
First, he commends him to your noble self.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Then certifies your Lordship that this night
He dreamt the boar had razèd off his helm.
Besides, he says there are two councils kept,
And that may be determined at the one
Which may make you and him to rue at th’ other.
Therefore he sends to know your Lordship’s pleasure,
If you will presently take horse with him
And with all speed post with him toward the north
To shun the danger that his soul divines.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Go, fellow, go. Return unto thy lord.
Bid him not fear the separated council.
His Honor and myself are at the one,
And at the other is my good friend Catesby,
Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us
Whereof I shall not have intelligence.
Tell him his fears are shallow, without instance.
And for his dreams, I wonder he’s so simple
To trust the mock’ry of unquiet slumbers.
To fly the boar before the boar pursues
Were to incense the boar to follow us
And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.
Go, bid thy master rise and come to me,
And we will both together to the Tower,
Where he shall see the boar will use us kindly.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: I’ll go, my lord, and tell him what you say.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: Many good morrows to my noble lord.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Good morrow, Catesby. You are early stirring.
What news, what news in this our tott’ring state?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: It is a reeling world indeed, my lord,
And I believe will never stand upright
Till Richard wear the garland of the realm.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: How “ wear the garland”? Dost thou mean the crown?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: Ay, my good lord.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: I’ll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders
Before I’ll see the crown so foul misplaced.
But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: Ay, on my life, and hopes to find you forward
Upon his party for the gain thereof;
And thereupon he sends you this good news,
That this same very day your enemies,
The kindred of the Queen, must die at Pomfret.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news,
Because they have been still my adversaries.
But that I’ll give my voice on Richard’s side
To bar my master’s heirs in true descent,
God knows I will not do it, to the death.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: God keep your Lordship in that gracious mind.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence,
That they which brought me in my master’s hate,
I live to look upon their tragedy.
Well, Catesby, ere a fortnight make me older
I’ll send some packing that yet think not on ’t.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: ’Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord,
When men are unprepared and look not for it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: O monstrous, monstrous! And so falls it out
With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey; and so ’twill do
With some men else that think themselves as safe
As thou and I, who, as thou know’st, are dear
To princely Richard and to Buckingham.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: The Princes both make high account of you—
Aside. For they account his head upon the Bridge.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: I know they do, and I have well deserved it.
Come on, come on. Where is your boar-spear, man?
Fear you the boar and go so unprovided?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.l: My lord, good morrow.— Good morrow, Catesby.—
You may jest on, but, by the Holy Rood,
I do not like these several councils, I.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours,
And never in my days, I do protest,
Was it so precious to me as ’tis now.
Think you but that I know our state secure,
I would be so triumphant as I am?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.l: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London,
Were jocund and supposed their states were sure,
And they indeed had no cause to mistrust;
But yet you see how soon the day o’ercast.
This sudden stab of rancor I misdoubt.
Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!
What, shall we toward the Tower? The day is spent.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Come, come. Have with you. Wot you what, my lord?
Today the lords you talked of are beheaded.

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.l: They, for their truth, might better wear their heads
Than some that have accused them wear their hats.
But come, my lord, let’s away.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Go on before. I’ll talk with this good fellow.
How now, sirrah? How goes the world with thee?

sp.speaker: PURSUIVANT
sp.l: The better that your Lordship please to ask.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: I tell thee, man, ’tis better with me now
Than when thou met’st me last where now we meet.
Then was I going prisoner to the Tower
By the suggestion of the Queen’s allies.
But now, I tell thee— keep it to thyself—
This day those enemies are put to death,
And I in better state than e’er I was.

sp.speaker: PURSUIVANT
sp.l: God hold it, to your Honor’s good content!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Gramercy, fellow. There, drink that for me.

sp.speaker: PURSUIVANT
sp.l: I thank your Honor.

sp.speaker: PRIEST
sp.l: Well met, my lord. I am glad to see your Honor.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.
I am in your debt for your last exercise.
Come the next sabbath, and I will content you.

sp.speaker: PRIEST
sp.l: I’ll wait upon your Lordship.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: What, talking with a priest, Lord Chamberlain?
Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest;
Your Honor hath no shriving work in hand.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Good faith, and when I met this holy man,
The men you talk of came into my mind.
What, go you toward the Tower?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: I do, my lord, but long I cannot stay there.
I shall return before your Lordship thence.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Nay, like enough, for I stay dinner there.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: And supper too, although thou know’st it not.—
Come, will you go?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: I’ll wait upon your Lordship.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Sir Richard Ratcliffe, with Halberds, carrying the nobles Rivers, Grey, and Vaughan to death at Pomfret.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.l: Sir Richard Ratcliffe, let me tell thee this:
Today shalt thou behold a subject die
For truth, for duty, and for loyalty.

sp.speaker: GREY
sp.l: God bless the Prince from all the pack of you!
A knot you are of damnèd bloodsuckers.

sp.speaker: VAUGHAN
sp.l: You live that shall cry woe for this hereafter.

sp.speaker: RATCLIFFE
sp.l: Dispatch. The limit of your lives is out.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.l: O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody prison,
Fatal and ominous to noble peers!
Within the guilty closure of thy walls,
Richard the Second here was hacked to death,
And, for more slander to thy dismal seat,
We give to thee our guiltless blood to drink.

sp.speaker: GREY
sp.l: Now Margaret’s curse is fall’n upon our heads,
When she exclaimed on Hastings, you, and I,
For standing by when Richard stabbed her son.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.l: Then cursed she Richard. Then cursed she Buckingham.
Then cursed she Hastings. O, remember, God,
To hear her prayer for them as now for us!
And for my sister and her princely sons,
Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood,
Which, as thou know’st, unjustly must be spilt.

sp.speaker: RATCLIFFE
sp.l: Make haste. The hour of death is expiate.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.l: Come, Grey. Come, Vaughan. Let us here embrace.
Farewell until we meet again in heaven.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Buckingham, Lord Stanley, Earl of Derby, Hastings, Bishop of Ely, Norfolk, Ratcliffe, Lovell, with others, at a table.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Now, noble peers, the cause why we are met
Is to determine of the coronation.
In God’s name, speak. When is the royal day?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Is all things ready for the royal time?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.l: It is, and wants but nomination.

sp.speaker: ELY
sp.l: Tomorrow, then, I judge a happy day.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Who knows the Lord Protector’s mind herein?
Who is most inward with the noble duke?

sp.speaker: ELY
sp.l: Your Grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: We know each other’s faces; for our hearts,
He knows no more of mine than I of yours,
Or I of his, my lord, than you of mine.—
Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: I thank his Grace, I know he loves me well.
But for his purpose in the coronation,
I have not sounded him, nor he delivered
His gracious pleasure any way therein.
But you, my honorable lords, may name the time,
And in the Duke’s behalf I’ll give my voice,
Which I presume he’ll take in gentle part.

sp.speaker: ELY
sp.l: In happy time here comes the Duke himself.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.
I have been long a sleeper; but I trust
My absence doth neglect no great design
Which by my presence might have been concluded.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Had you not come upon your cue, my lord,
William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part—
I mean your voice for crowning of the King.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder.
His Lordship knows me well and loves me well.—
My lord of Ely, when I was last in Holborn
I saw good strawberries in your garden there;
I do beseech you, send for some of them.

sp.speaker: ELY
sp.l: Marry and will, my lord, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.
Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business
And finds the testy gentleman so hot
That he will lose his head ere give consent
His master’s child, as worshipfully he terms it,
Shall lose the royalty of England’s throne.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Withdraw yourself awhile. I’ll go with you.

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.l: We have not yet set down this day of triumph.
Tomorrow, in my judgment, is too sudden,
For I myself am not so well provided
As else I would be, were the day prolonged.

sp.speaker: ELY
sp.l: Where is my lord the Duke of Gloucester?
I have sent for these strawberries.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: His Grace looks cheerfully and smooth this morning.
There’s some conceit or other likes him well
When that he bids good morrow with such spirit.
I think there’s never a man in Christendom
Can lesser hide his love or hate than he,
For by his face straight shall you know his heart.

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.l: What of his heart perceive you in his face
By any livelihood he showed today?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Marry, that with no man here he is offended,
For were he, he had shown it in his looks.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I pray you all, tell me what they deserve
That do conspire my death with devilish plots
Of damnèd witchcraft, and that have prevailed
Upon my body with their hellish charms?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: The tender love I bear your Grace, my lord,
Makes me most forward in this princely presence
To doom th’ offenders, whosoe’er they be.
I say, my lord, they have deservèd death.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Then be your eyes the witness of their evil.
Look how I am bewitched! Behold mine arm
Is like a blasted sapling withered up;
And this is Edward’s wife, that monstrous witch,
Consorted with that harlot, strumpet Shore,
That by their witchcraft thus have markèd me.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: If they have done this deed, my noble lord—

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: If? Thou protector of this damnèd strumpet,
Talk’st thou to me of “ ifs”? Thou art a traitor.—
Off with his head. Now by Saint Paul I swear
I will not dine until I see the same.—
Lovell and Ratcliffe, look that it be done.—
The rest that love me, rise and follow me.

div.stage: They exit. Lovell and Ratcliffe remain, with the Lord Hastings.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: Woe, woe for England! Not a whit for me,
For I, too fond, might have prevented this.
Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm,
And I did scorn it and disdain to fly.
Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble,
And started when he looked upon the Tower,
As loath to bear me to the slaughterhouse.
O, now I need the priest that spake to me!
I now repent I told the pursuivant,
As too triumphing, how mine enemies
Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered,
And I myself secure in grace and favor.
O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse
Is lighted on poor Hastings’ wretched head.

sp.speaker: RATCLIFFE
sp.l: Come, come, dispatch. The Duke would be at dinner.
Make a short shrift. He longs to see your head.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: O momentary grace of mortal men,
Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!
Who builds his hope in air of your good looks
Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast,
Ready with every nod to tumble down
Into the fatal bowels of the deep.

sp.speaker: LOVELL
sp.l: Come, come, dispatch. ’Tis bootless to exclaim.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.l: O bloody Richard! Miserable England,
I prophesy the fearfull’st time to thee
That ever wretched age hath looked upon.—
Come, lead me to the block. Bear him my head.
They smile at me who shortly shall be dead.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Enter Richard and Buckingham, in rotten armor, marvelous ill-favored.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Come, cousin, canst thou quake and change thy color,
Murder thy breath in middle of a word,
And then again begin, and stop again,
As if thou were distraught and mad with terror?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian,
Speak, and look back, and pry on every side,
Tremble and start at wagging of a straw,
Intending deep suspicion. Ghastly looks
Are at my service, like enforcèd smiles,
And both are ready, in their offices,
At any time to grace my stratagems.
But what, is Catesby gone?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: He is; and see he brings the Mayor along.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Lord Mayor—

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Look to the drawbridge there!

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Hark, a drum!

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Catesby, o’erlook the walls.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Lord Mayor, the reason we have sent—

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Look back! Defend thee! Here are enemies.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: God and our innocence defend and guard us!

div.stage: Enter Lovell and Ratcliffe, with Hastings’ head.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Be patient. They are friends, Ratcliffe and Lovell.

sp.speaker: LOVELL
sp.l: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor,
The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: So dear I loved the man that I must weep.
I took him for the plainest harmless creature
That breathed upon the Earth a Christian;
Made him my book, wherein my soul recorded
The history of all her secret thoughts.
So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue
That, his apparent open guilt omitted—
I mean his conversation with Shore’s wife—
He lived from all attainder of suspects.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Well, well, he was the covert’st sheltered traitor
That ever lived.—
Would you imagine, or almost believe,
Were ’t not that by great preservation
We live to tell it, that the subtle traitor
This day had plotted, in the council house,
To murder me and my good lord of Gloucester?

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: Had he done so?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: What, think you we are Turks or infidels?
Or that we would, against the form of law,
Proceed thus rashly in the villain’s death,
But that the extreme peril of the case,
The peace of England, and our persons’ safety
Enforced us to this execution?

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: Now fair befall you! He deserved his death,
And your good Graces both have well proceeded
To warn false traitors from the like attempts.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: I never looked for better at his hands
After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.
Yet had we not determined he should die
Until your Lordship came to see his end
( Which now the loving haste of these our friends,
Something against our meanings, have prevented),
Because, my lord, I would have had you heard
The traitor speak and timorously confess
The manner and the purpose of his treasons,
That you might well have signified the same
Unto the citizens, who haply may
Misconster us in him, and wail his death.

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: But, my good lord, your Graces’ words shall serve
As well as I had seen and heard him speak;
And do not doubt, right noble princes both,
But I’ll acquaint our duteous citizens
With all your just proceedings in this case.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: And to that end we wished your Lordship here,
T’ avoid the censures of the carping world.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Which since you come too late of our intent,
Yet witness what you hear we did intend.
And so, my good Lord Mayor, we bid farewell.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Go after, after, cousin Buckingham.
The Mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post.
There, at your meetest vantage of the time,
Infer the bastardy of Edward’s children.
Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen
Only for saying he would make his son
Heir to the Crown— meaning indeed his house,
Which, by the sign thereof, was termèd so.
Moreover, urge his hateful luxury
And bestial appetite in change of lust,
Which stretched unto their servants, daughters, wives,
Even where his raging eye or savage heart,
Without control, lusted to make a prey.
Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person:
Tell them when that my mother went with child
Of that insatiate Edward, noble York
My princely father then had wars in France,
And, by true computation of the time,
Found that the issue was not his begot,
Which well appearèd in his lineaments,
Being nothing like the noble duke my father.
Yet touch this sparingly, as ’twere far off,
Because, my lord, you know my mother lives.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Doubt not, my lord. I’ll play the orator
As if the golden fee for which I plead
Were for myself. And so, my lord, adieu.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard’s Castle,
Where you shall find me well accompanied
With reverend fathers and well-learnèd bishops.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: I go; and towards three or four o’clock
Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Go, Lovell, with all speed to Doctor Shaa.
To Ratcliffe. Go thou to Friar Penker. Bid them both
Meet me within this hour at Baynard’s Castle.
Now will I go to take some privy order
To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight,
And to give order that no manner person
Have any time recourse unto the Princes.

sp.speaker: SCRIVENER
sp.l: Here is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings,
Which in a set hand fairly is engrossed,
That it may be today read o’er in Paul’s.
And mark how well the sequel hangs together:
Eleven hours I have spent to write it over,
For yesternight by Catesby was it sent me;
The precedent was full as long a-doing,
And yet within these five hours Hastings lived,
Untainted, unexamined, free, at liberty.
Here’s a good world the while! Who is so gross
That cannot see this palpable device?
Yet who so bold but says he sees it not?
Bad is the world, and all will come to naught
When such ill dealing must be seen in thought.

div.head: Scene 7
div.stage: Enter Richard and Buckingham at several doors.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: How now, how now? What say the citizens?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord,
The citizens are mum, say not a word.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Touched you the bastardy of Edward’s children?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy
And his contract by deputy in France;
Th’ unsatiate greediness of his desire
And his enforcement of the city wives;
His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy,
As being got, your father then in France,
And his resemblance being not like the Duke.
Withal, I did infer your lineaments,
Being the right idea of your father,
Both in your form and nobleness of mind;
Laid open all your victories in Scotland,
Your discipline in war, wisdom in peace,
Your bounty, virtue, fair humility;
Indeed, left nothing fitting for your purpose
Untouched or slightly handled in discourse.
And when mine oratory drew toward end,
I bid them that did love their country’s good
Cry “ God save Richard, England’s royal king!”

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: And did they so?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: No. So God help me, they spake not a word
But, like dumb statues or breathing stones,
Stared each on other and looked deadly pale;
Which when I saw, I reprehended them
And asked the Mayor what meant this willful silence.
His answer was, the people were not used
To be spoke to but by the Recorder.
Then he was urged to tell my tale again:
“ Thus saith the Duke. Thus hath the Duke inferred”—
But nothing spoke in warrant from himself.
When he had done, some followers of mine own,
At lower end of the hall, hurled up their caps,
And some ten voices cried “ God save King Richard!”
And thus I took the vantage of those few.
“ Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,” quoth I.
“ This general applause and cheerful shout
Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard”—
And even here brake off and came away.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: What tongueless blocks were they! Would they not speak?
Will not the Mayor then and his brethren come?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: The Mayor is here at hand. Intend some fear;
Be not you spoke with but by mighty suit.
And look you get a prayer book in your hand
And stand between two churchmen, good my lord,
For on that ground I’ll make a holy descant.
And be not easily won to our requests.
Play the maid’s part: still answer “ nay,” and take it.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I go. An if you plead as well for them
As I can say “ nay” to thee for myself,
No doubt we bring it to a happy issue.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Go, go, up to the leads. The Lord Mayor knocks.
Welcome, my lord. I dance attendance here.
I think the Duke will not be spoke withal.
Now, Catesby, what says your lord to my request?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: He doth entreat your Grace, my noble lord,
To visit him tomorrow or next day.
He is within, with two right reverend fathers,
Divinely bent to meditation,
And in no worldly suits would he be moved
To draw him from his holy exercise.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Return, good Catesby, to the gracious duke.
Tell him myself, the Mayor, and aldermen,
In deep designs, in matter of great moment
No less importing than our general good,
Are come to have some conference with his Grace.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: I’ll signify so much unto him straight.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Ah ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!
He is not lolling on a lewd love-bed,
But on his knees at meditation;
Not dallying with a brace of courtesans,
But meditating with two deep divines;
Not sleeping, to engross his idle body,
But praying, to enrich his watchful soul.
Happy were England would this virtuous prince
Take on his Grace the sovereignty thereof.
But sure I fear we shall not win him to it.

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: Marry, God defend his Grace should say us nay.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: I fear he will. Here Catesby comes again.
Now, Catesby, what says his Grace?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: He wonders to what end you have assembled
Such troops of citizens to come to him,
His Grace not being warned thereof before.
He fears, my lord, you mean no good to him.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Sorry I am my noble cousin should
Suspect me that I mean no good to him.
By heaven, we come to him in perfect love,
And so once more return and tell his Grace.
When holy and devout religious men
Are at their beads, ’tis much to draw them thence,
So sweet is zealous contemplation.

div.stage: Enter Richard aloft, between two Bishops.

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: See where his Grace stands, ’tween two clergymen.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Two props of virtue for a Christian prince,
To stay him from the fall of vanity;
And, see, a book of prayer in his hand,
True ornaments to know a holy man.—
Famous Plantagenet, most gracious prince,
Lend favorable ear to our requests,
And pardon us the interruption
Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: My lord, there needs no such apology.
I do beseech your Grace to pardon me,
Who, earnest in the service of my God,
Deferred the visitation of my friends.
But, leaving this, what is your Grace’s pleasure?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above
And all good men of this ungoverned isle.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I do suspect I have done some offense
That seems disgracious in the city’s eye,
And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: You have, my lord. Would it might please your Grace,
On our entreaties, to amend your fault.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Know, then, it is your fault that you resign
The supreme seat, the throne majestical,
The sceptered office of your ancestors,
Your state of fortune, and your due of birth,
The lineal glory of your royal house,
To the corruption of a blemished stock,
Whiles in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts,
Which here we waken to our country’s good,
The noble isle doth want her proper limbs—
Her face defaced with scars of infamy,
Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants,
And almost shouldered in the swallowing gulf
Of dark forgetfulness and deep oblivion;
Which to recure, we heartily solicit
Your gracious self to take on you the charge
And kingly government of this your land,
Not as Protector, steward, substitute,
Or lowly factor for another’s gain,
But as successively, from blood to blood,
Your right of birth, your empery, your own.
For this, consorted with the citizens,
Your very worshipful and loving friends,
And by their vehement instigation,
In this just cause come I to move your Grace.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I cannot tell if to depart in silence
Or bitterly to speak in your reproof
Best fitteth my degree or your condition.
If not to answer, you might haply think
Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded
To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty,
Which fondly you would here impose on me.
If to reprove you for this suit of yours,
So seasoned with your faithful love to me,
Then on the other side I checked my friends.
Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first,
And then, in speaking, not to incur the last,
Definitively thus I answer you:
Your love deserves my thanks, but my desert
Unmeritable shuns your high request.
First, if all obstacles were cut away
And that my path were even to the crown
As the ripe revenue and due of birth,
Yet so much is my poverty of spirit,
So mighty and so many my defects,
That I would rather hide me from my greatness,
Being a bark to brook no mighty sea,
Than in my greatness covet to be hid
And in the vapor of my glory smothered.
But, God be thanked, there is no need of me,
And much I need to help you, were there need.
The royal tree hath left us royal fruit,
Which, mellowed by the stealing hours of time,
Will well become the seat of majesty,
And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.
On him I lay that you would lay on me,
The right and fortune of his happy stars,
Which God defend that I should wring from him.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: My lord, this argues conscience in your Grace,
But the respects thereof are nice and trivial,
All circumstances well considerèd.
You say that Edward is your brother’s son;
So say we too, but not by Edward’s wife.
For first was he contract to Lady Lucy—
Your mother lives a witness to his vow—
And afterward by substitute betrothed
To Bona, sister to the King of France.
These both put off, a poor petitioner,
A care-crazed mother to a many sons,
A beauty-waning and distressèd widow,
Even in the afternoon of her best days,
Made prize and purchase of his wanton eye,
Seduced the pitch and height of his degree
To base declension and loathed bigamy.
By her in his unlawful bed he got
This Edward, whom our manners call “ the Prince.”
More bitterly could I expostulate,
Save that, for reverence to some alive,
I give a sparing limit to my tongue.
Then, good my lord, take to your royal self
This proffered benefit of dignity,
If not to bless us and the land withal,
Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry
From the corruption of abusing times
Unto a lineal, true-derivèd course.

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: Do, good my lord. Your citizens entreat you.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffered love.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: O, make them joyful. Grant their lawful suit.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Alas, why would you heap this care on me?
I am unfit for state and majesty.
I do beseech you, take it not amiss;
I cannot, nor I will not, yield to you.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: If you refuse it, as in love and zeal
Loath to depose the child, your brother’s son—
As well we know your tenderness of heart
And gentle, kind, effeminate remorse,
Which we have noted in you to your kindred
And equally indeed to all estates—
Yet know, whe’er you accept our suit or no,
Your brother’s son shall never reign our king,
But we will plant some other in the throne,
To the disgrace and downfall of your house.
And in this resolution here we leave you.—
Come, citizens. Zounds, I’ll entreat no more.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham!

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: Call him again, sweet prince. Accept their suit.
If you deny them, all the land will rue it.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Will you enforce me to a world of cares?
Call them again. I am not made of stones,
But penetrable to your kind entreaties,
Albeit against my conscience and my soul.
Cousin of Buckingham and sage, grave men,
Since you will buckle Fortune on my back,
To bear her burden, whe’er I will or no,
I must have patience to endure the load;
But if black scandal or foul-faced reproach
Attend the sequel of your imposition,
Your mere enforcement shall acquittance me
From all the impure blots and stains thereof,
For God doth know, and you may partly see,
How far I am from the desire of this.

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: God bless your Grace! We see it and will say it.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Then I salute you with this royal title:
Long live Richard, England’s worthy king!

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Tomorrow may it please you to be crowned?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Even when you please, for you will have it so.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Tomorrow, then, we will attend your Grace,
And so most joyfully we take our leave.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Come, let us to our holy work again.—
Farewell, my cousin. Farewell, gentle friends.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Queen Elizabeth, with the Duchess of York, and the Lord Marquess of Dorset, at one door; Anne, Duchess of Gloucester with Clarence’s daughter, at another door.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Who meets us here? My niece Plantagenet
Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?
Now, for my life, she’s wandering to the Tower,
On pure heart’s love, to greet the tender prince.—
Daughter, well met.

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.l: God give your Graces both
A happy and a joyful time of day.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: As much to you, good sister. Whither away?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.l: No farther than the Tower, and, as I guess,
Upon the like devotion as yourselves,
To gratulate the gentle princes there.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Kind sister, thanks. We’ll enter all together.
And in good time here the Lieutenant comes.—
Master Lieutenant, pray you, by your leave,
How doth the Prince and my young son of York?

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.l: Right well, dear madam. By your patience,
I may not suffer you to visit them.
The King hath strictly charged the contrary.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: The King? Who’s that?

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.l: I mean, the Lord Protector.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: The Lord protect him from that kingly title!
Hath he set bounds between their love and me?
I am their mother. Who shall bar me from them?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: I am their father’s mother. I will see them.

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.l: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother.
Then bring me to their sights. I’ll bear thy blame
And take thy office from thee, on my peril.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.l: No, madam, no. I may not leave it so.
I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.l: Let me but meet you ladies one hour hence,
And I’ll salute your Grace of York as mother
And reverend looker-on of two fair queens.
To Anne. Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster,
There to be crownèd Richard’s royal queen.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Ah, cut my lace asunder
That my pent heart may have some scope to beat,
Or else I swoon with this dead-killing news!

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.l: Despiteful tidings! O, unpleasing news!

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.l: Be of good cheer, mother. How fares your Grace?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: O Dorset, speak not to me. Get thee gone.
Death and destruction dogs thee at thy heels.
Thy mother’s name is ominous to children.
If thou wilt outstrip death, go, cross the seas,
And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell.
Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughterhouse,
Lest thou increase the number of the dead
And make me die the thrall of Margaret’s curse,
Nor mother, wife, nor England’s counted queen.

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.l: Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.
To Dorset. Take all the swift advantage of the hours.
You shall have letters from me to my son
In your behalf, to meet you on the way.
Be not ta’en tardy by unwise delay.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: O ill-dispersing wind of misery!
O my accursèd womb, the bed of death!
A cockatrice hast thou hatched to the world,
Whose unavoided eye is murderous.

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.l: Come, madam, come. I in all haste was sent.

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.l: And I with all unwillingness will go.
O, would to God that the inclusive verge
Of golden metal that must round my brow
Were red-hot steel to sear me to the brains!
Anointed let me be with deadly venom,
And die ere men can say “ God save the Queen.”

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory.
To feed my humor, wish thyself no harm.

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.l: No? Why? When he that is my husband now
Came to me as I followed Henry’s corse,
When scarce the blood was well washed from his hands
Which issued from my other angel husband
And that dear saint which then I weeping followed—
O, when, I say, I looked on Richard’s face,
This was my wish: be thou, quoth I, accursed
For making me, so young, so old a widow;
And, when thou wedd’st, let sorrow haunt thy bed;
And be thy wife, if any be so mad,
More miserable by the life of thee
Than thou hast made me by my dear lord’s death.
Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again,
Within so small a time my woman’s heart
Grossly grew captive to his honey words
And proved the subject of mine own soul’s curse,
Which hitherto hath held my eyes from rest,
For never yet one hour in his bed
Did I enjoy the golden dew of sleep,
But with his timorous dreams was still awaked.
Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick,
And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Poor heart, adieu. I pity thy complaining.

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.l: No more than with my soul I mourn for yours.

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.l: Farewell, thou woeful welcomer of glory.

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.l: Adieu, poor soul that tak’st thy leave of it.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Go thou to Richmond, and good fortune guide thee.
To Anne. Go thou to Richard, and good angels tend thee.
To Queen Elizabeth. Go thou to sanctuary, and good thoughts possess thee.
I to my grave, where peace and rest lie with me.
Eighty-odd years of sorrow have I seen,
And each hour’s joy wracked with a week of teen.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower.—
Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes
Whom envy hath immured within your walls—
Rough cradle for such little pretty ones.
Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow
For tender princes, use my babies well.
So foolish sorrows bids your stones farewell.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Sound a sennet. Enter Richard in pomp; Buckingham, Catesby, Ratcliffe, Lovell, and others, including a Page.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Stand all apart.— Cousin of Buckingham.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: My gracious sovereign.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Give me thy hand.
sp.stage: Here he ascendeth the throne. Sound trumpets.
sp.l: Thus high, by thy advice
And thy assistance is King Richard seated.
But shall we wear these glories for a day,
Or shall they last and we rejoice in them?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Still live they, and forever let them last.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ah, Buckingham, now do I play the touch,
To try if thou be current gold indeed:
Young Edward lives; think now what I would speak.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Say on, my loving lord.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Why, Buckingham, I say I would be king.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Why so you are, my thrice-renownèd lord.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ha! Am I king? ’Tis so— but Edward lives.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: True, noble prince.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: O bitter consequence
That Edward still should live “ true noble prince”!
Cousin, thou wast not wont to be so dull.
Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead,
And I would have it suddenly performed.
What sayst thou now? Speak suddenly. Be brief.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Your Grace may do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Tut, tut, thou art all ice; thy kindness freezes.
Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Give me some little breath, some pause, dear lord,
Before I positively speak in this.
I will resolve you herein presently.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: The King is angry. See, he gnaws his lip.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I will converse with iron-witted fools
And unrespective boys. None are for me
That look into me with considerate eyes.
High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.—
Boy!

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Know’st thou not any whom corrupting gold
Will tempt unto a close exploit of death?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.l: I know a discontented gentleman
Whose humble means match not his haughty spirit.
Gold were as good as twenty orators,
And will, no doubt, tempt him to anything.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.l: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I partly know the man. Go, call him hither, boy.
Aside. The deep-revolving witty Buckingham
No more shall be the neighbor to my counsels.
Hath he so long held out with me, untired,
And stops he now for breath? Well, be it so.
How now, Lord Stanley, what’s the news?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.l: Know, my loving lord,
The Marquess Dorset, as I hear, is fled
To Richmond, in the parts where he abides.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Come hither, Catesby. Rumor it abroad
That Anne my wife is very grievous sick.
I will take order for her keeping close.
Inquire me out some mean poor gentleman,
Whom I will marry straight to Clarence’ daughter.
The boy is foolish, and I fear not him.
Look how thou dream’st! I say again, give out
That Anne my queen is sick and like to die.
About it, for it stands me much upon
To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.
Aside. I must be married to my brother’s daughter,
Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.
Murder her brothers, and then marry her—
Uncertain way of gain. But I am in
So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin.
Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.
Is thy name Tyrrel?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.l: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Art thou indeed?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.l: Prove me, my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Dar’st thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.l: Please you. But I had rather kill two enemies.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Why then, thou hast it. Two deep enemies,
Foes to my rest, and my sweet sleep’s disturbers,
Are they that I would have thee deal upon.
Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.l: Let me have open means to come to them,
And soon I’ll rid you from the fear of them.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Thou sing’st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel.
Go, by this token. Rise, and lend thine ear.
sp.stage: Tyrrel rises, and Richard whispers to him. Then Tyrrel steps back.
sp.l: There is no more but so. Say it is done,
And I will love thee and prefer thee for it.

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.l: I will dispatch it straight.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: My lord, I have considered in my mind
The late request that you did sound me in.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Well, let that rest. Dorset is fled to Richmond.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: I hear the news, my lord.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Stanley, he is your wife’s son. Well, look unto it.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: My lord, I claim the gift, my due by promise,
For which your honor and your faith is pawned—
Th’ earldom of Hereford and the movables
Which you have promisèd I shall possess.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Stanley, look to your wife. If she convey
Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: What says your Highness to my just request?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I do remember me, Henry the Sixth
Did prophesy that Richmond should be king,
When Richmond was a little peevish boy.
A king perhaps—

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: My lord—

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: How chance the prophet could not at that time
Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: My lord, your promise for the earldom—

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Richmond! When last I was at Exeter,
The Mayor in courtesy showed me the castle
And called it Rougemont, at which name I started,
Because a bard of Ireland told me once
I should not live long after I saw Richmond.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: My lord—

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ay, what’s o’clock?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: I am thus bold to put your Grace in mind
Of what you promised me.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Well, but what’s o’clock?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Upon the stroke of ten.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Well, let it strike.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Why let it strike?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Because that, like a jack, thou keep’st the stroke
Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.
I am not in the giving vein today.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: Why then, resolve me whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Thou troublest me; I am not in the vein.

div.stage: He exits, and is followed by all but Buckingham.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.l: And is it thus? Repays he my deep service
With such contempt? Made I him king for this?
O, let me think on Hastings and be gone
To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.l: The tyrannous and bloody act is done,
The most arch deed of piteous massacre
That ever yet this land was guilty of.
Dighton and Forrest, who I did suborn
To do this piece of ruthless butchery,
Albeit they were fleshed villains, bloody dogs,
Melted with tenderness and mild compassion,
Wept like two children in their deaths’ sad story.
“ O thus,” quoth Dighton, “ lay the gentle babes.”
“ Thus, thus,” quoth Forrest, “ girdling one another
Within their alabaster innocent arms.
Their lips were four red roses on a stalk,
And in their summer beauty kissed each other.
A book of prayers on their pillow lay,
Which once,” quoth Forrest, “ almost changed my mind,
But, O, the devil—” There the villain stopped;
When Dighton thus told on: “ We smotherèd
The most replenishèd sweet work of nature
That from the prime creation e’er she framed.”
Hence both are gone with conscience and remorse;
They could not speak; and so I left them both
To bear this tidings to the bloody king.
And here he comes.— All health, my sovereign lord.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.l: If to have done the thing you gave in charge
Beget your happiness, be happy then,
For it is done.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: But did’st thou see them dead?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.l: I did, my lord.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.l: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them,
But where, to say the truth, I do not know.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after-supper,
When thou shalt tell the process of their death.
Meantime, but think how I may do thee good,
And be inheritor of thy desire.
Farewell till then.

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.l: I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: The son of Clarence have I pent up close,
His daughter meanly have I matched in marriage,
The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham’s bosom,
And Anne my wife hath bid this world goodnight.
Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims
At young Elizabeth, my brother’s daughter,
And by that knot looks proudly on the crown,
To her go I, a jolly thriving wooer.

sp.speaker: RATCLIFFE
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Good or bad news, that thou com’st in so bluntly?

sp.speaker: RATCLIFFE
sp.l: Bad news, my lord. Morton is fled to Richmond,
And Buckingham, backed with the hardy Welshmen,
Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near
Than Buckingham and his rash-levied strength.
Come, I have learned that fearful commenting
Is leaden servitor to dull delay;
Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary;
Then fiery expedition be my wing,
Jove’s Mercury, and herald for a king.
Go, muster men. My counsel is my shield.
We must be brief when traitors brave the field.

div.head: Scene 4

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: So now prosperity begins to mellow
And drop into the rotten mouth of death.
Here in these confines slyly have I lurked
To watch the waning of mine enemies.
A dire induction am I witness to,
And will to France, hoping the consequence
Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical.
Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret. Who comes here?

div.stage: Enter Duchess of York and Queen Elizabeth.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Ah, my poor princes! Ah, my tender babes,
My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets,
If yet your gentle souls fly in the air
And be not fixed in doom perpetual,
Hover about me with your airy wings
And hear your mother’s lamentation.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Hover about her; say that right for right
Hath dimmed your infant morn to agèd night.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: So many miseries have crazed my voice
That my woe-wearied tongue is still and mute.
Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet;
Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs
And throw them in the entrails of the wolf?
When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Dead life, blind sight, poor mortal living ghost,
Woe’s scene, world’s shame, grave’s due by life usurped,
Brief abstract and record of tedious days,
Rest thy unrest on England’s lawful earth,
Unlawfully made drunk with innocent blood.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Ah, that thou wouldst as soon afford a grave
As thou canst yield a melancholy seat,
Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.
Ah, who hath any cause to mourn but we?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: If ancient sorrow be most reverend,
Give mine the benefit of seigniory,
And let my griefs frown on the upper hand.
If sorrow can admit society,
Tell over your woes again by viewing mine.
I had an Edward till a Richard killed him;
I had a husband till a Richard killed him.
Thou hadst an Edward till a Richard killed him;
Thou hadst a Richard till a Richard killed him.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: I had a Richard too, and thou did’st kill him;
I had a Rutland too; thou holp’st to kill him.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard killed him.
From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept
A hellhound that doth hunt us all to death—
That dog, that had his teeth before his eyes,
To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood;
That excellent grand tyrant of the Earth,
That reigns in gallèd eyes of weeping souls;
That foul defacer of God’s handiwork
Thy womb let loose to chase us to our graves.
O upright, just, and true-disposing God,
How do I thank thee that this carnal cur
Preys on the issue of his mother’s body
And makes her pew-fellow with others’ moan!

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: O Harry’s wife, triumph not in my woes!
God witness with me, I have wept for thine.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Bear with me. I am hungry for revenge,
And now I cloy me with beholding it.
Thy Edward he is dead, that killed my Edward,
Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;
Young York, he is but boot, because both they
Matched not the high perfection of my loss.
Thy Clarence he is dead that stabbed my Edward,
And the beholders of this frantic play,
Th’ adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey,
Untimely smothered in their dusky graves.
Richard yet lives, hell’s black intelligencer,
Only reserved their factor to buy souls
And send them thither. But at hand, at hand
Ensues his piteous and unpitied end.
Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray,
To have him suddenly conveyed from hence.
Cancel his bond of life, dear God I pray,
That I may live and say “ The dog is dead.”

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come
That I should wish for thee to help me curse
That bottled spider, that foul bunch-backed toad!

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: I called thee then “ vain flourish of my fortune.”
I called thee then poor shadow, “ painted queen,”
The presentation of but what I was,
The flattering index of a direful pageant,
One heaved a-high to be hurled down below,
A mother only mocked with two fair babes,
A dream of what thou wast, a garish flag
To be the aim of every dangerous shot,
A sign of dignity, a breath, a bubble,
A queen in jest, only to fill the scene.
Where is thy husband now? Where be thy brothers?
Where are thy two sons? Wherein dost thou joy?
Who sues and kneels and says “ God save the Queen?”
Where be the bending peers that flattered thee?
Where be the thronging troops that followed thee?
Decline all this, and see what now thou art:
For happy wife, a most distressèd widow;
For joyful mother, one that wails the name;
For one being sued to, one that humbly sues;
For queen, a very caitiff crowned with care;
For she that scorned at me, now scorned of me;
For she being feared of all, now fearing one;
For she commanding all, obeyed of none.
Thus hath the course of justice whirled about
And left thee but a very prey to time,
Having no more but thought of what thou wast
To torture thee the more, being what thou art.
Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not
Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?
Now thy proud neck bears half my burdened yoke,
From which even here I slip my weary head
And leave the burden of it all on thee.
Farewell, York’s wife, and queen of sad mischance.
These English woes shall make me smile in France.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: O, thou well-skilled in curses, stay awhile,
And teach me how to curse mine enemies.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days;
Compare dead happiness with living woe;
Think that thy babes were sweeter than they were,
And he that slew them fouler than he is.
Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse.
Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: My words are dull. O, quicken them with thine!

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Thy woes will make them sharp and pierce like mine.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Why should calamity be full of words?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Windy attorneys to their clients’ woes,
Airy succeeders of intestate joys,
Poor breathing orators of miseries,
Let them have scope; though what they will impart
Help nothing else, yet do they ease the heart.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: If so, then be not tongue-tied. Go with me,
And in the breath of bitter words let’s smother
My damnèd son that thy two sweet sons smothered.
The trumpet sounds. Be copious in exclaims.

div.stage: Enter King Richard and his train, including Catesby.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Who intercepts me in my expedition?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: O, she that might have intercepted thee,
By strangling thee in her accursèd womb,
From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Hid’st thou that forehead with a golden crown
Where should be branded, if that right were right,
The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown
And the dire death of my poor sons and brothers?
Tell me, thou villain-slave, where are my children?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence,
And little Ned Plantagenet his son?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Where is the gentle Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Where is kind Hastings?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: A flourish, trumpets! Strike alarum, drums!
Let not the heavens hear these telltale women
Rail on the Lord’s anointed. Strike, I say!
Either be patient and entreat me fair,
Or with the clamorous report of war
Thus will I drown your exclamations.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Art thou my son?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Then patiently hear my impatience.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Madam, I have a touch of your condition,
That cannot brook the accent of reproof.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: O, let me speak!

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Do then, but I’ll not hear.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: I will be mild and gentle in my words.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: And brief, good mother, for I am in haste.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Art thou so hasty? I have stayed for thee,
God knows, in torment and in agony.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: And came I not at last to comfort you?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: No, by the Holy Rood, thou know’st it well.
Thou cam’st on Earth to make the Earth my hell.
A grievous burden was thy birth to me;
Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy;
Thy school days frightful, desp’rate, wild, and furious;
Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous;
Thy age confirmed, proud, subtle, sly, and bloody,
More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred.
What comfortable hour canst thou name,
That ever graced me with thy company?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Faith, none but Humfrey Hower, that called your Grace
To breakfast once, forth of my company.
If I be so disgracious in your eye,
Let me march on and not offend you, madam.—
Strike up the drum.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: I prithee, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: You speak too bitterly.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Hear me a word,
For I shall never speak to thee again.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.l: Either thou wilt die by God’s just ordinance
Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror,
Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish
And nevermore behold thy face again.
Therefore take with thee my most grievous curse,
Which in the day of battle tire thee more
Than all the complete armor that thou wear’st.
My prayers on the adverse party fight,
And there the little souls of Edward’s children
Whisper the spirits of thine enemies
And promise them success and victory.
Bloody thou art; bloody will be thy end.
Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse
Abides in me. I say amen to her.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Stay, madam. I must talk a word with you.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: I have no more sons of the royal blood
For thee to slaughter. For my daughters, Richard,
They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens,
And therefore level not to hit their lives.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: You have a daughter called Elizabeth,
Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: And must she die for this? O, let her live,
And I’ll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty,
Slander myself as false to Edward’s bed,
Throw over her the veil of infamy.
So she may live unscarred of bleeding slaughter,
I will confess she was not Edward’s daughter.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Wrong not her birth. She is a royal princess.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: To save her life, I’ll say she is not so.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Her life is safest only in her birth.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: And only in that safety died her brothers.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Lo, at their birth good stars were opposite.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: No, to their lives ill friends were contrary.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: True, when avoided grace makes destiny.
My babes were destined to a fairer death
If grace had blessed thee with a fairer life.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Cousins, indeed, and by their uncle cozened
Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life.
Whose hand soever launched their tender hearts,
Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction.
No doubt the murd’rous knife was dull and blunt
Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart,
To revel in the entrails of my lambs.
But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame,
My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys
Till that my nails were anchored in thine eyes,
And I, in such a desp’rate bay of death,
Like a poor bark of sails and tackling reft,
Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise
And dangerous success of bloody wars
As I intend more good to you and yours
Than ever you or yours by me were harmed!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: What good is covered with the face of heaven,
To be discovered, that can do me good?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Th’ advancement of your children, gentle lady.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Unto the dignity and height of fortune,
The high imperial type of this Earth’s glory.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Flatter my sorrow with report of it.
Tell me what state, what dignity, what honor,
Canst thou demise to any child of mine?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Even all I have— ay, and myself and all—
Will I withal endow a child of thine;
So in the Lethe of thy angry soul
Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs
Which thou supposest I have done to thee.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Be brief, lest that the process of thy kindness
Last longer telling than thy kindness’ date.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Then know that from my soul I love thy daughter.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: My daughter’s mother thinks it with her soul.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: What do you think?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul.
So from thy soul’s love didst thou love her brothers,
And from my heart’s love I do thank thee for it.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning.
I mean that with my soul I love thy daughter
And do intend to make her Queen of England.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Well then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Even he that makes her queen. Who else should be?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: What, thou?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Even so. How think you of it?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: How canst thou woo her?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: That would I learn of you,
As one being best acquainted with her humor.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: And wilt thou learn of me?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Madam, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Send to her, by the man that slew her brothers,
A pair of bleeding hearts; thereon engrave
“ Edward” and “ York.” Then haply will she weep.
Therefore present to her— as sometime Margaret
Did to thy father, steeped in Rutland’s blood—
A handkerchief, which say to her did drain
The purple sap from her sweet brother’s body,
And bid her wipe her weeping eyes withal.
If this inducement move her not to love,
Send her a letter of thy noble deeds;
Tell her thou mad’st away her uncle Clarence,
Her uncle Rivers, ay, and for her sake
Mad’st quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: You mock me, madam. This is not the way
To win your daughter.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: There is no other way,
Unless thou couldst put on some other shape
And not be Richard, that hath done all this.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Say that I did all this for love of her.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee,
Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Look what is done cannot be now amended.
Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes,
Which after-hours gives leisure to repent.
If I did take the kingdom from your sons,
To make amends I’ll give it to your daughter.
If I have killed the issue of your womb,
To quicken your increase I will beget
Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter.
A grandam’s name is little less in love
Than is the doting title of a mother.
They are as children but one step below,
Even of your metal, of your very blood,
Of all one pain, save for a night of groans
Endured of her for whom you bid like sorrow.
Your children were vexation to your youth,
But mine shall be a comfort to your age.
The loss you have is but a son being king,
And by that loss your daughter is made queen.
I cannot make you what amends I would;
Therefore accept such kindness as I can.
Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul
Leads discontented steps in foreign soil,
This fair alliance quickly shall call home
To high promotions and great dignity.
The king that calls your beauteous daughter wife
Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother.
Again shall you be mother to a king,
And all the ruins of distressful times
Repaired with double riches of content.
What, we have many goodly days to see!
The liquid drops of tears that you have shed
Shall come again, transformed to orient pearl,
Advantaging their love with interest
Of ten times double gain of happiness.
Go then, my mother; to thy daughter go.
Make bold her bashful years with your experience;
Prepare her ears to hear a wooer’s tale;
Put in her tender heart th’ aspiring flame
Of golden sovereignty; acquaint the Princess
With the sweet silent hours of marriage joys;
And when this arm of mine hath chastisèd
The petty rebel, dull-brained Buckingham,
Bound with triumphant garlands will I come
And lead thy daughter to a conqueror’s bed,
To whom I will retail my conquest won,
And she shall be sole victoress, Caesar’s Caesar.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: What were I best to say? Her father’s brother
Would be her lord? Or shall I say her uncle?
Or he that slew her brothers and her uncles?
Under what title shall I woo for thee,
That God, the law, my honor, and her love
Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Infer fair England’s peace by this alliance.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Which she shall purchase with still-lasting war.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Tell her the King, that may command, entreats—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: That, at her hands, which the King’s King forbids.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Say she shall be a high and mighty queen.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: To vail the title, as her mother doth.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Say I will love her everlastingly.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: But how long shall that title “ ever” last?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Sweetly in force unto her fair life’s end.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: But how long fairly shall her sweet life last?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: As long as heaven and nature lengthens it.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: As long as hell and Richard likes of it.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Say I, her sovereign, am her subject low.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Then plainly to her tell my loving tale.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: O no, my reasons are too deep and dead—
Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their graves.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Now by my George, my Garter, and my crown—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Profaned, dishonored, and the third usurped.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I swear—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: By nothing, for this is no oath.
Thy George, profaned, hath lost his lordly honor;
Thy Garter, blemished, pawned his knightly virtue;
Thy crown, usurped, disgraced his kingly glory.
If something thou wouldst swear to be believed,
Swear then by something that thou hast not wronged.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Then, by myself—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Thyself is self-misused.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Now, by the world—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: ’Tis full of thy foul wrongs.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: My father’s death—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Thy life hath it dishonored.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Why then, by God.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: God’s wrong is most of all.
If thou didst fear to break an oath with Him,
The unity the King my husband made
Thou hadst not broken, nor my brothers died.
If thou hadst feared to break an oath by Him,
Th’ imperial metal circling now thy head
Had graced the tender temples of my child,
And both the Princes had been breathing here,
Which now, two tender bedfellows for dust,
Thy broken faith hath made the prey for worms.
What canst thou swear by now?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: The time to come.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: That thou hast wrongèd in the time o’erpast;
For I myself have many tears to wash
Hereafter time, for time past wronged by thee.
The children live whose fathers thou hast slaughtered,
Ungoverned youth, to wail it in their age;
The parents live whose children thou hast butchered,
Old barren plants, to wail it with their age.
Swear not by time to come, for that thou hast
Misused ere used, by times ill-used o’erpast.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: As I intend to prosper and repent,
So thrive I in my dangerous affairs
Of hostile arms! Myself myself confound,
Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours,
Day, yield me not thy light, nor night thy rest,
Be opposite all planets of good luck
To my proceeding if, with dear heart’s love,
Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts,
I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter.
In her consists my happiness and thine.
Without her follows to myself and thee,
Herself, the land, and many a Christian soul,
Death, desolation, ruin, and decay.
It cannot be avoided but by this;
It will not be avoided but by this.
Therefore, dear mother— I must call you so—
Be the attorney of my love to her;
Plead what I will be, not what I have been;
Not my deserts, but what I will deserve.
Urge the necessity and state of times,
And be not peevish found in great designs.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ay, if the devil tempt you to do good.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Shall I forget myself to be myself?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ay, if your self’s remembrance wrong yourself.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Yet thou didst kill my children.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: But in your daughter’s womb I bury them,
Where, in that nest of spicery, they will breed
Selves of themselves, to your recomforture.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: And be a happy mother by the deed.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.l: I go. Write to me very shortly,
And you shall understand from me her mind.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Bear her my true love’s kiss; and so, farewell.
Relenting fool and shallow, changing woman!
How now, what news?

sp.speaker: RATCLIFFE
sp.l: Most mighty sovereign, on the western coast
Rideth a puissant navy. To our shores
Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends,
Unarmed and unresolved to beat them back.
’Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral;
And there they hull, expecting but the aid
Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Some light-foot friend post to the Duke of Norfolk—
Ratcliffe thyself, or Catesby. Where is he?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: Here, my good lord.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Catesby, fly to the Duke.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: I will, my lord, with all convenient haste.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ratcliffe, come hither. Post to Salisbury.
When thou com’st thither— To Catesby. Dull, unmindful villain,
Why stay’st thou here and go’st not to the Duke?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: First, mighty liege, tell me your Highness’ pleasure,
What from your Grace I shall deliver to him.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: O true, good Catesby. Bid him levy straight
The greatest strength and power that he can make
And meet me suddenly at Salisbury.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: RATCLIFFE
sp.l: What, may it please you, shall I do at Salisbury?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?

sp.speaker: RATCLIFFE
